"Kevin O'Sullivan" Tue, 1 Jun 2004 09:42:50 +0100
>>> One of the concerns that I (and developers) have is that we will
>>> end up with thousands of test cases, many of which will involve
>>> using substantial amounts of MockObjects to set up test cases and
>>> that all this will become too much of an overhead to manage &
>>> maintain. 

More on maintenance below. Regarding "thousands of test cases":

* Some test coverage is better than none. Don't "let the perfect be
  the enemy of the good": write some testcases now! "A journey of a
  thousand testcases" :-)

* I'm suspecting that you are equating testing with unit testing:
  since you have thousands of methods you must therefore have
  thousands of testcases. Again, some testing is better than none; but
  also, consider writing a few functional "scenario" suites that
  cover high-value, must-not-break usecases. They will tend to
  exercise a lotta underlying code, and they can be written so as to
  "spread the cost" of creating real (as opposed to mock) objects. Use
  TestSetup to wrapper your suite, create your BigRealObject's in a
  onetime setUp() (or "along the way" during your scenario's
  execution), and each testcase in the suite can use them.

A single functional "scenario" will not, of course, be as
diagnostically useful as many unit tests, but at least you will get
that immediate red/green, un/broken feedback:

>>> changing code in the future will involve analysis of not only the
>>> project code but also the junit test code

"J. B. Rainsberger" Wed, 02 Jun 2004 00:54:11 -0400
>> Tests are not overhead; they are the safety net that /enables/ you
>> to make changes confidently. They /save/ you time & effort. Without
>> tests, how do you know that a change you made didn't break
>> something?

Hear, hear! But you probably already, deep down inside, know that ...
which is why you are currently probably testing MANUALLY. So when
you are comparing relative to the status quo, shouldn't you be
including your current test costs? Or are you really not testing AT
ALL now?

>> Bottom line: do you want it to work or not? If you want it to work,
>> you have to test it.

Hear, hear! But note he does *not* say "unit test": don't forget the
other types of testing you need to do, and don't forget that you can

"Chappell, Simon P" Wed, 2 Jun 2004 13:59:30 -0500
> use JUnit for unit tests and to drive both functional and load tests
> (a little pragmatic automation in action! :-)

Correct! Which is why ...

> Here are my thoughts on the pros and cons of using unit tests:

> cons:

> 1. You actually have to write unit test code.
> 2. You have to maintain unit test code.

* s/unit//. Don't get hung up on the "Unit" part of "JUnit"--you can
  indeed use it to drive many other types of testing.

* consider tool assist. Several IDEs, notably Eclipse (and those based
  upon it), now provide excellent support for both JUnit and
  refactoring. These can take much of the drudgery out of both writing
  and maintaining testcases.
